titleStmt.title: Doha, Qatar National Library (مكتبة قطرالوطنية), HC.MS.2017.0053

respStmt.resp: Edited by Michael Marx in collaboration with Tobias J. Jocham et. al. TEI version created by Yasmin Faghihi and Huw Jones

availability.p: Image credits: Qatar National Library, Heritage Library.

summary.p: Single folio, Shelfmark: HC.MS.2017.0053, Writing surface: parchment, Text: 34:45-48, Lines per page: 5, Dimensions: 148 x 210 mm, Script style: kūfī, gold Ductus: D.I/D.II and D.Vb; Estimated date of production: 10th century. Provenance: Medieval provenance: Two folios bear medieval waqf inscriptions indicating that parts of the manuscript were in the Great Mosque of Qayrawan in medieval times (see http://islamicart.museumwnf.org/database_item.php?id=object;ISL;tn;Mus01;3;en&pageD=N; Déroche 1992, p. 67; Sotheby’s, London, 12 October 2005, lot 6). However, the folios in the Bibliothèque Nationale (and possibly other fragments) must have been located in Egypt in medieval and/or early modern times, probably in the ʿAmr Mosque in Fustat, as the two folios BNF 5178f were part of the group acquired by Louis Asselin de Cherville in the late eighteenth century in Egypt, which came from the Amr Mosque in Fustat (Guesdon and Vernay-Nouri 2001, no. 60, p. 91). Thus the manuscript may have been partially dispersed in medieval/early modern times. Modern provenance: The manuscript must have been partially dispersed by the early 20th century and certainly before 1927, as the folio in the Museum of Fine Arts Boston was acquired by Denman Waldo Ross, the Harvard professor, artist and collector, in the early years of the 20th century and donated to that museum in 1927. Recent provenance of this folio: Christie’s, London, 27 April 2017, lot 2. Sister Leaves: Over 110 leaves from this Qur’ān are known and widely dispersed. The sister leaves are as follows (single folios unless otherwise stated, in order of Qur’ānic text, the QNL folio marked in bold): (1) 002:215-002:217; Christie’s, London, 4 October 2012, lot 2; (2) 002:218-002:220; Doha, Museum of Islamic Art, MS.776.2011; (3) 004:170-004:173; Kuwait, al-Sabah Collection, LNS203 (Curatola, Keene and Kaoukji 2010, no. 16, p. 59; Atil 1990, no. 1); (4) 005:041; Sotheby’s, London, 31 March 2021, lot 1; (5) 48 folios, including 005:006-005:007, 005:015-005:016, 005:018, 005:027; Riyadh, National Museum (Al-Ghabban et al. 2010, no. 302, p. 520); (6) 006:114-006:116; Boston, Museum of Fine Arts, 27.791; (7) 009:091-009:092; Christie’s, London, 20 October 1994, lot 227; (8) 009:103-009:105; Christie’s, London, 20 October 1994, lot 227; (9) 010:070-010:071; Raqqada, National Museum of Islamic Art, formerly Tunis, National Library, Rutbi 198 (these leaves were formerly in the Great Mosque of Qayrawan, transferred in 1967 to National Library, Tunis, Rutbi 198, then moved to the Raqqada Museum in 1983 (see http://islamicart.museumwnf.org/database_item.php?id=object;ISL;tn;Mus01;3;en&pageD=N. The illuminated page was illustrated in Lings and Safadi 1976, no. 16, p. 29, Pl. I, p. 17, when it was still in the National Library, Tunis). (10) 010:073-010:075, 010:093-010:094 (bifolium); (Stanley 1995, no. 11, pp. 60-61); (11) 017:009-017:011; Paris, Bibliothèque Nationale, MS. Arabe 5178f (Déroche 1983, no. 111, p. 96); (12) 017:085-017:088; Sotheby’s, London, 26 April 1990, lot 140; (13) 017:085-017:087; Asian Civilizations Museum, Singapore; (14) 018:002-018:006; Sotheby’s, London, 11 October 1991, lot 892; (15) 018:074; Tunis, National Institute of Archaeology and Art (illuminated page with text on verso); (16) 019:059-029:062; Lygo Collection (Kwiatkowski, n.d., no. 21, pp. 44-45); (17) 021:050-021:054; Tunis, National Library, Rutbi 198 (Lings and Safadi 1976, no. 17, p. 26); (18) 022:037-022:40; Doha, Museum of Islamic Art, MS.779.2011; (19) 022:043-022:044; Raqqada, National Museum of Islamic Art, formerly Tunis, National Library, Rutbi 198 (These leaves were formerly in the Great Mosque of Qayrawan, transferred in 1967 to National Library, Tunis, Rutbi 198, then moved to the Raqqada Museum in 1983, see http://islamicart.museumwnf.org/database_item.php?id=object;ISL;tn;Mus01;3;en&pageD=N. They were illustrated in [De Carthage à Kairouan, no. 346], when they were in the National Library, Tunis); (20) 022:063-022:064; Raqqada, National Museum of Islamic Art, formerly Tunis, National Library, Rutbi 198. (These leaves were formerly in the Great Mosque of Qayrawan, transferred in 1967 to National Library, Tunis, Rutbi 198, then moved to the Raqqada Museum in 1983, see http://islamicart.museumwnf.org/database_item.php?id=object;ISL;tn;Mus01;3;en&pageD=N. They were illustrated in [De Carthage à Kairouan, no. 346], when they were in the National Library, Tunis); (21) 023:029-023:033; Sotheby’s, London, 10 October 1988, lot 170; (22) 027:012-027:014; Bonhams, 17 October 2002, lot 5; (23) 029:007-029:009; Sotheby’s, Geneva, 25 June 1985, lot 5; (24) 029:010-029:012; Sotheby’s, London, 21 November 1985, lot 290; (25) 029:013-029:015; Sotheby’s, London, 23 October 1992, lot 550; (26) 029:024-029:025; Sotheby’s, London, 1 June 1987, lot 78; (27) 029:031-029:034; Institute of Ismaili Studies, London, today: Aga Khan Museum Toronto AKN 480; (28) 029:039-029:042; Sotheby’s, London, 22 May 1986, lot 248; (29) 032:029-033:001; Paris, Bibliothèque Nationale, MS. Arabe 5178f (Déroche 1983, no. 111, p. 96); (30) 034:042-034:044; Sotheby’s, London, 13 October 1989, lot 77; (31) 034:044-034:048; Sotheby’s, London, 21 November 1985, lot 291; (32) 034:043-034:044; Khalili Collection, London, KFQ 84 (Déroche 1992, no. 19, p. 67); (33) 034:045-034:048; Qatar National Library, HC.MS.2017.0053; (34) 034:048-034:052; Doha, Museum of Islamic Art, MS.768.2011; (35) 040:075-040:078; Kuwait, Tareq Rajab Museum TSR-011-MS; (36) 042:037-042:040; Doha, Museum of Islamic Art, MS.769.2011; (37) 042:046-042:048; Beit al-Qur’ān, Bahrain (Beit al-Qur’an 1996, p.81); (38) 052:047-052:049; 053:031-053:032 (bifolium); Raqqada National Museum of Islamic Art, Tunisia; (39) 058:002-059:001 (bifolium); Raqqada, National Museum of Islamic Art (Lings and Safadi 1976, no. 19, p. 26; De Carthage à Kairouan 1983, no. 348, pp. 264-5), (40) 13 folios: 059:011-059:015; 059:019-059:020; 060:012-060:013; 061:001-061:011; 062:001-062:011; 064:005:064:008; 065:001:065:003; Christie’s, London, 9 October 1990, lot 45; (41) 070:044-071:004; Christie’s, London, 4 October 2012, lot 1; (42) 071:004-071:007; Christie’s, London, 23 October 2007, lot 3; (43) 071:025-071:028; Sotheby’s, London, 18 October 2001, lot 4; (44) 078:038-078:040, with illuminated sura heading of sura 079; Sotheby’s, London, 12 October 2005, lot 6; (45) 080:022-080:036; Sotheby’s, London, 15 October 1984, lot 218; (46) 080:040-081:002; Copenhagen, The David Collection; (47) 083:003-083:012, 085:002-085:009 (bifolium); Falk 1985, no. 1; (48) 089:004-089:009; Raqqada National Museum of Islamic Art, Tunisia; (49) 099:007-100:005; Raqqada National Museum of Islamic Art, Tunisia. Bibliography: Bernard Quaritch Ltd, The Holy Qur’an in Manuscript, Jeddah, 1991. R. Fendall (ed.), Islamic Calligraphy, Sam Fogg Ltd, Catalogue 27, London, n.d.

support.p: Codicology and Illumination: Recto is flesh side; verso is hair side. Single verse divisions are marked with gold rosettes outlined in blue within the text area. Fifth verse divisions are marked with a larger gold roundel within the text area containing the word ḫamsa ("five [verses]") in gold kūfī script. Observation of other folios from the same Qur’ān shows that tenth verse divisions were marked within the text with an illuminated roundel containing abjad letters to indicate the verse count, with an adjacent larger illuminated roundel in the margin containing the exact verse count written in gold kūfī script. Estimated date of production: 10th century. D.I and D.II script are generally associated with the ninth century and first half of the tenth century (Déroche 1992, pp. 36-37), and the presence on this folio of the inward curving ascenders of the lām-ʾalif of the D.Vb type, suggests the later part of this range, i.e. the tenth century, when New Style scripts started to influence mature kūfī scripts. M. Rammah has attributed this Qur’ān to the second half of the tenth century (see http://islamicart.museumwnf.org/database_item.php?id=object;ISL;tn;Mus01;3;en&pageD=N) It has been noted that the abjad system used in this Qur’ān is the so-called “eastern” abjad, which was not generally used in the Maghrib, leading to a suggestion that this Qur’ān was produced in the Central Islamic lands or Iran, overturning the earlier attribution to Qayrawan (Stanley 1995, p.16; Lings and Safadi 1976, nos. 16-19, p. 26). This copy of the Qur’ān appears to have been bound in 30 sections, and it has been estimated that the total number of folios would originally have been around 2,000 folios (Stanley 1995, p.16).

summary.p: Diacritics: Letter-pointing consists of diagonal dashes in brown ink. Vocalisation consists of red, green and blue dots. The script is generally close to D.I, but there are two forms of the lām-ʾalif. One is the conventional form associated with D.I, in which the ascenders diverge (verso, fourth line); while the other has ascenders that initially diverge and then curve inwards again at the top (recto, final letter of the fifth line). The latter form is associated with D.Vb and New Style scripts, which were in use in the tenth century. These variations are also noted on other folios from this Qur’ān, as well as instances of D.Vc letter forms (Stanley 1995, p.18). François Déroche notes that in addition to the precisely applied dashes of the letter-pointing, the scribe has included minute letters ‘ayn and rā’ to differentiate from their homographs (Déroche 1992, no. 19, p. 67). There are no examples of these marks on the present folio, but there are two instances in which the letter ḥā’ is differentiated from its homographs, the letters ǧīm and ḫāʾ, by the use of a distinctive angled mark ( > ) below the letter. Thus this Qur’ān features a very precise diacritical system. As with other early examples of Qur’ānic chrysography, the script is either written in a gold “ink” in which powdered gold is mixed with a binder, or first written with a size or glair and gold powder is then applied to this, leaving gold letters that follow the form of the adhesive script beneath. The gold is then outlined in brown ink to give it visual and graphic definition. There is very limited use of mašq (“horizontal stretching of the letter forms”).

scriptDesc.scriptNote: kūfī D.I, kūfī D.Vb, kūfī D.II
